casebody.data:
ROBERT QUIGLEY against JOEL MIDDLETON. Feb 1829. A writ of restitution issued after, although tested before the death of she defendant or person against whom it issues, will be quashed. And ihe application to quash may be made on behalf of a party interested. Wall moved to set aside the writ of restitution issued in this Ease upon the reversal by this court of a judgment of forcible entry and detainer, which bad been brought here by certiorari. He read affidavits to prove that Joel Middleton, the person against whom the writ issued, died on the 10th of September 1828, and to prove that ihe sheriff did not receive the writ of restitution until the 8th of October lastj the writ was tested on the firsi Tuesday of September, which was the 2d day of September. He also read a deed from Joel Middleton to Benjamin South, dated in August 1828, for the premises mentioned in the writ of restitution ; and he stated that he made this motion in behalf of the purchaser B. South, and of the executors of Joel Middleton, Hamilton and Scott resisted the motion,

and contended :

1. That tire writ was good because it was tested before the death of Middleton, although it issued after.

2. That if the writ of restitution was irregular, it ought Co be set aside only upon the application of a person who liad a right to make stick application. That the only persons who bad a right to make the application, were the heirs of Joel Middleton. That the executors had no right in the land, and that the purchaser having put chased pendente lite had no right to make the application.

Ch. Justice

delivered the opinion of the court, that the writ of restitution must he quashed, because it issued after the death of Middleton. Writ quashed.
